newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian rate cut surprises markets.
newsitem.headline: Australian rate cut surprises markets.

text.p: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cut official interest rates by half a percent on Friday -- a move that surprised markets given the hawkish statements two weeks ago of the central bank governor.
Australia's official cash rate was cut by 0.5 percentage points to 5.5 percent. It was the fourth cut since last July and took rates to their lowest level since August 1994.
Official rates in Australia are now level with U.S. rates, the first time since September 1984, a move that immediately saw the local dollar sold off to a three-month low of US$0.7665.
The RBA had been under political pressure to cut rates, with the prime minister and treasurer arguing the 1997/98 budget released last week set the stage for lower rates.
After the announcement, Treasurer Peter Costello said domestic influences, including a good budget outcome, had allowed for the latest easing.
"The domestic events gave us a unique window of opportunity and you've seen the reduction in interest rates as a consequence," Costello told reporters.
In justifying the cut, RBA Governor Ian Macfarlane said low inflation, some scope for faster economic growth and ongoing fiscal consolidation gave the bank room to ease.

"The above considerations -- namely, inflation forecast to fall below two percent, and economic activity providing scope for further expansion -- amount to a prima facie case for an easing in policy," Macfarlane said in a statement.
Many in the market were surprised by the cut, while some did not agree with the RBA's reasons for easing.
"It's a bit hard to make a case for this cut and I think the RBA's statement on the reasons was the weakest of the four so far," J.P. Morgan senior economist John Kyiakopoulos said.

The cut also represented a sharp turnaround from Macfarlane's comments two weeks ago to a parliamentary committee, when he said there was no economic gain to be had from another movement in official interest rates.
Rumours that Treasury Secretary Ted Evans, the government's representative on the RBA board, had been pushing for a rate cut had circulated financial markets in recent weeks.
Government ministers had also been saying the budget released last week had set the scene for lower rates.
"I was a bit surprised because I would have thought you would have needed to see one of the big indicators fall in the hole," Axiom Funds Management senior economist Matthew Drennan.
"At this point in the cycle a 50 point cut is a pretty big stimulus (to the economy)," Drennan said.
But the final factor in the decision to cut rates appears to have been wages data released on Thursduay showing wages had not been rising as quickly as previously thought.
Annual average weekly ordinary time earnings rose 4.3 percent in the year to February, down from the preliminary figure of 4.6 percent reported earlier this month.
Wages growth of 4.5 percent is seen as the RBA's "line in the sand" above which it threatens the pursuit of low inflation.
"Yesterday's wages data suggested that wage growth was not accelerating at an unacceptable pace," Colonial State Bank group economist Hans Kunnen said.
Kunnen had thought a rate cut was justified, but said given the RBA's public statements he was surprised at the decision.
